La représentante du groupe, du nom de Chantal est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Chantal est âgé de 40 ans et vit au Bénin. Chantal  est marié à un mécanicien du nom de Kenedy. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés dont trois sont les leurs. Les enfants vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Chantal  a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Chantal  mène comme activité la vente des vivres. A côté de cette activité Chantal  vend de la friperie. Chantal  mène cette activité depuis vingt ans  environs. Chantal s’approvisionne dans l'un des marchés du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu Chantal  sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe MINSOMAHU, un troisième crédit. Les crédits reçus antérieurement ont été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
The group MINSOMAHU is composed of seven persons who lives in the same district. This is the third time that this group has requested financial aid from ALIDé for boosting their businesses. The group’s representative, by the name of Chantal, is the one with her hand raised in the photo. She is 40 years old and lives in Benin. She is married to a mechanic by the name of Kenedy, and they have five children who are all in school. Three of the children are their own. The children live together with their parents. Chantal has attended middle school. 

To support herself and her family, Chantal runs a business selling staple foods. Aside from this, she sells second-hand clothing. She has been in this business for about 20 years. She gets her supplies from the markets of Benin. Seeking to satisfy her customers and to increase her turnover and her revenues, she and the other members of the group MINSOMAHU are requesting a third loan. The loans previously received have indeed been repaid.

loans.use: to buy bales of second-hand clothing

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child.

Eva has a bakery where she sells breads and pastries including loaf breads and cakes. She has had this business for 6 years and has requested a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy ingredients for bread making.

Eva has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to make bread

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy flour, milk, sugar, spices and ingredients needed to cook and sell food products

loans.name: Ayde Esperanza

texts.es: Ayde Esperanza de 27 años de edad, habita en casa propia junto con su querida hija Liliana de 7 años de edad. La razón de que Ayde viva sola es porque su compañero de vida emigro hace unos años a Estados Unidos y con la ayuda de él y de su árduo trabajo es como va saliendo adelante. Ella es una joven muy emprendedora con muchos deseos de superación y de ver a su hija en mejores condiciones a las que ella ha tenido.  Hace algunos años logró establecer una pequeña tiendita en  su lugar de residencia en la cual vende diversidad de productos como: golosinas, aceite, pan dulce, cereales, verduras, zapatos y muchas cosas más. Este negocio es la principal fuente de ingresos de Ayde ya que la situación de su esposo no es estable y hay algunos meses que no recibe remesas ya que su esposo no cuenta con un trabajo fijo en el país en que se encuentra. Ha estado pensando mucho en la forma de hacer crecer su tienda y lograr aumentar su nivel de ventas ya que por el momento está sería la única forma de lograr sostenerse económicamente. Esto la motivo a solicitar este crédito a INTEGRAL para invertir en su tienda en la compra de variedad de productos tales como: verduras, arroz, azúcar, frijoles, pan dulce, bebidas, detergente, golosinas. Etc. Sinceramente espera poder mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en: Ayde Esperanza, 27 years old, lives in her home with her dear daughter Liliana who's 7 years old. The reason that Ayde lives alone is because her life partner emigrated to the United States several years ago and with the help of his arduous work she has been able to stay afloat. She is a very entrepreneurial young person with a great desire for self-improvement and seeing her daughter in better conditions than those which she has had. Several years ago she managed to establish a small store in her home residence from which she sells a diversity of products like: candy, oil, sweet bread, cereals, vegetables, shoes, and many other things. This business is the main source of income for Ayde since her husband's situation is not stable and there are some months when she doesn't receive a remittance of money as her husband is not able to rely on a permanent job in the country in which he finds himself. She has been thinking a lot about how to make her store grow and manage to increase the level in sales as for the time being this is the only way to manage to support herself economically. This motivated her to apply to Integral for a loan in order to invest in her store purchasing a variety products such as: vegetables, rice, sugar, beans, sweet bread, drinks, detergent, candy, etc. She sincerely hopes to be able to better her quality of life and that of her family.

loans.use: to buy a variety of products like: vegetables, rice, sugar, beans, sweet bread, drinks, detergent, candies, etc.

loans.name: New Horizons [Nuevos Horizontes] Group

texts.es:
La señora Aracely Feliciana es casada, tiene 28 años D. edad, cursó los grados D. estudios primarios, tiene 2 hijos 1 D. los cuales estudia, se dedica ala tejeduría D. telas típicas: servilletas, cortes, y sabanas; inició este trabajo como operaria y hasta el momento lleva 12 años D. experiencia, cuenta con el poyo D. su esposo quien se dedica al mismo trabajo.

Organiza un grupo con el fin D. solicitar un préstamo que servirá para la compra D. materiales: hilos y labores D. diferentes diseños y colores, el el futuro espera contar con suficiente capital y mejorar sus ingresos. Las demás integrantes del grupo se dedican: a la tejeduría, venta D. comida, y a la venta D. productos D. belleza.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aracely Feliciana is married, 28 years old, has completed primary school and has 2 children, 1 of whom attends school. She weaves traditional fabrics: napkins, cuts of cloth and sheets. She began this job as a worker, currently has 12 years of experience and also counts on the support of her husband who is in the same line of work.

She has organised a group with the aim of soliciting a loan which will allow them to purchase materials: thread and needlework with various designs and colours. In future she hopes to have enough capital to improve her income. The others in the group work in: weaving, food sales and the sale of beauty products.

loans.use: Purchase thread

loans.name: Salma's Group

texts.en:
Salma is a very supportive lady who, along with her husband, makes and sells paper envelopes. Her husband collects the orders from different stationery shops and also delivers the envelopes to them on their requested date. She is 49 years old and doesn’t have any children.  

She has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business, because her husband has a big order to fill. With the loan, he will buy paper and glue in bulk quantities that will allow him to complete the orders on time and increase his profits. Her husband has been operating the business for the past 10 years, and Salma is confident that an investment will be a productive one for him and will increase his profits. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Salma”.

loans.use: To buy paper and glue for her envelope making and selling business.

loans.name: Jyparkul's Group

texts.en: With money received from this loan, Jyparkul wants to purchase more farm animals for breeding. In the future, she wishes to see all her children get wed. Jyparkul is 47 and, together with her husband, she has raised two sons and three daughters. The older daughter is married and lives separately with her family, two daughters are at school, the older son works in construction, and the younger one is a farmer. In order to earn money to meet their daily needs, this family breeds cattle. At the moment they keep four cows and Jyparkul sells about 50-60 liters of milk a day. In this way she earns about 12,000 soms per month. This profit made it possible to improve their living conditions and increase their number of cattle. Jyparkul is the leader of this group. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young and ambitious socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase farm animals for breeding

loans.name: Evert Antonio

texts.es: Everth Antonio tiene su negocio que es la venta de granos básicos, el siempre se ha preocupado por brindar un buen servicio. El motivo del crédito que solicita es para la compra de arroz, frijoles, aceite, azúcar, maíz, trigo entre otros productos. El tiene su negocio desde hace 5 años y solicito el crédito para la compra de mercadería para surtir su tienda y así poder ofrecer variedad de productos a sus clientes, ella es una persona muy trabajadora dice estar eternamente agradecida por el trato recibido en la institución.
texts.en:
Evert Antonio has a business that sells dry goods. He has always been concerned about providing good service. The reason he is requesting this loan is so that he can buy rice, beans, oil, sugar, corn, wheat, and other products. His business has been in operation for five years, so he is requesting this loan so that he can buy merchandise to restock his store. This will also help him to offer a variety of products to his customers.

Evert is an extremely hardworking individual. He says that he is eternally grateful for the service he has received from the organization.

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, oil, sugar, corn, wheat, and other products.

loans.name: Leonor

texts.es:
Leonor es socia del Banco Comunal Diamantes, es socia D. FINCA Peru desD. hace 1 año y medio.
Leonor se dedica a la venta D. cereales en Ica, con los primeros préstamos que recibió aumentó su capital D. negocio y pudo comprar cereales en grandes cantidades, ella esta muy agradecida a Finca por el apoyo que le brindaron, aprendió a poder ser mejor negociante y a poder ahorrar y eso es lo que ella mas valora. El préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra D. cereales. Su meta es construir su casa.
texts.en: Leonor is a member of the communal bank Diamantes and has been a member of FINCA Peru for a year and a half. Leonor sells grains in Ica. With the first loans she received she increased her working capital and bought dry grains in bulk. She is very grateful to FINCA for the support extended to her. She learned how to be a better business person and be able to save and that it is what she most values. The loan she is asking for is to purchase dry grains. Her goal is to build a house.

loans.use: to buy dry grains.

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe KOTOGNOGONTALA sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 38  ans, et ont en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygamiques à Kamalen Sirakoro un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso. 
Elles sont à leur sixième prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, qui ne cesse d’augmenter.
 MAIMOUNA, mène l’activité achat – vente de poisons (frais et fumés) il ya environ 3ans. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 3 gros paniers  de poisons frais et 2 cartons de poissons fumés. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso.
Elle les revend au  marché de Kamalen Sirakoro à une place fixe et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.000FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The five members of the KOTOGNOGONTALA group are all married women, around 38 years old, each having about 3 children. Most of them live in polygamous families in the Kamalen Sirakoro district of the city of Sikasso.

They are on their sixth loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to meet the needs of their continuously growing customer base. MAIMOUNA has been buying and selling fish (fresh and smoked) for about 3 years now.

With her loan, she plans to buy 3 large basketfuls of fresh fish and 2 packages of smoked fish. She gets her supplies from the big market in the city of Sikasso.

She resells the fish for cash at the market in Kamalen Sirakoro, where she has a permanent spot, and to family members. Her customers are both men and women.

She expects to make an average monthly profit of 27,000 FCFA. She uses some of her profits to cover daily family expenses and saves the rest.

loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Santos Mendaly

texts.es:
Santos, vive con su esposo y tres hijos, son dependientes y ella se dedica a la crianza y venta de pollos, aprendió junto a su esposo, quien la apoya en todo momento, esta granja la tiene en su casa, la atiende todo el día al igual que los quehaceres del hogar.
Ella quiere comprar pollos de engorde, para aumentar la granja, ya que se acerca la temporada navideña donde muchos clientes demandan.
Ella tiene el propósito de crecer la granja, tanto en espacio como el número de pollos, además ofrecerles su familia una vida más cómoda.
texts.en:
Santos lives with her husband and three children who depend on her.  She raises and sells chickens, having learned from her husband, and does this along with the housework.

She wants to buy chickens to fatten up and expand the farm, now that the Christmas season is approaching and she’s getting many requests from customers.

She intends to grow her farm, both in space and in the number of chickens, and provide a more comfortable life for her family.

loans.use: to buy chickens.

loans.name: Girasoles Group

texts.en:
Girasoles (Sunflower) Trust Bank was formed five years in San Juan Ostuncalco, a small village outside of Quetzaltenango, which is located in the western highlands of Guatemala. The seven women members of the Trust Bank are all neighbors and have known each other for many years. Each member makes the hour-long trip each way to the Quetzaltenango market on a weekly basis to buy goods and materials for their businesses and, ultimately, to sell their products. This is the fifth loan for the Sunflower Trust Bank, and all previous loans were paid on time and in full.

Vicenta Marroquin, named after her grandmother, is 28 years old and has three young girls.She has been an active member of the Sunflower Trust Bank since its inception. Vicenta is a seamstress and creates colorful traditional Mayan clothing, a craft she learned as a child from her aunt. Through previous loans from Friendship Bridge, Vicenta started a bakery business, with two other Trust Bank members more than a year ago. She plans to split her current loan between her two business, using half to buy additional thread and cloth and the remaining amount to buy powder, sugar, and other baking goods.  It is Vicenta’s dream to own her own bakery. She feels that it is a blessing that lenders around the world have shown such kindness to help her and her fellow Sunflower Trust Bank members.

loans.use: To buy more fabric, thread, flower and sugar for her two businesses.

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
Natividad is 62 years old and married with six children.  She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines, and has requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks to sell.

Natividad has borrowed and repaid seven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for four years, and also earns an income from rice retailing.

Natividad aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks to sell.

loans.name: 04.10.4 Nam Ngạn Thanh Hóa Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Liên is 50 years old and she is married with 3 children. Liên lives with no dependents in Thanh Hoa city, a urban town in Thanh Hoa province. Mrs. Liên operates a food stall/restaurant selling snacks. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. The main harship that Liên faces in her business is the lack of capital. Liên is requesting a loan to purchase materials to make processed food to sell. With her business profit, she hopes for her business to do well, for her children to find a good job, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

Liên is the leader of a 5-member group, the 4 Nam Ngạn solidarity group. In 2010, Liên joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Liên has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

loans.use: to purchase materials to make processed food to sell

loans.name: Sok Cheng

texts.en:
Sok Cheng is 30 years old.  She is married, blessed with one child and lives in Kandal Province, Cambodia.  She has been growing mangoes for more than four years, earning approximately $4 per day.   Her husband is a construction worker who earns about $4 per day.   

Sok Cheng is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase fertilizer, pesticide and seeds for cultivating mangoes.  In the future, she would like to purchase more farmland and send her child to a good school.  Moreover, she hopes to build a new house as soon as possible.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, pesticide and seeds to grow mangoes

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mrs. Mary E. is 31 years old with three (3) children. She sells foodstuffs for the community. She wishes that the above amount comes to her for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Mama A. is a palm oil producer. She buys the palm fruits direct from the farm, prepares the oil, and sells to retailers in the market. She lives in the community where the central market is located.

The cost of preparing the oil is very expensive. She is seeking a Kiva loan of $900.00 to enable her to produce on a larger scale.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria and her husband Mario have been living on their land for about ten years now. They have been able to slowly build their home out of hard work, although it is still admittedly in need of much improvement. Maria has a 7 year old daughter who she works hard to feed and educate. Her husband is a field worker who is mostly employed in big farms outside of their town. Meanwhile, Maria tends to their own piece of land with the help of Mario whenever he is out of work or she really needs him. They hope to invest in fertilizer and pesticides to preserve the crops they have already planted.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of one the new Communal Banks formed in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Anzuelo Baba Communal Bank are part of an association of rice farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their organization, El Anzuelo Asociacion, works cooperatively to help their members cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. Most recently, El Anzuelo was able to start a program that improved their members access to watering services.

The members of La Asociacion El Anzuelo de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each other’s guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Baba

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financing, they have turned to loan sharks, paying between 100% and 240% annual interest. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and earn fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is a severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Hellen would like to buy 2 steers

loans.name: Ilda Leonor Paulo

texts.pt:
Location: Guachene area – Catembe
Client: Ilda Leonor Paulo M.
Activity: Retail
Loan amount: 10,000 Mozambique Meticais (MT) (US$ 400.00)
Use: Purchase products for resale
Start date: 08/16/2007
End date: 11/07/2008

Ilda Leonor Paulo M. was born in Maputo in 1966. She attended school only until the 7th grade due to her father’s early death. Her mother was not financially able to cover the costs of her children's schooling as she was unemployed. At the age of 18 she married her husband with whom she has 5 children. She tried working as a housekeeper but couldn’t stand it, so she started her own small business at the age of 19. She has been running it since then.

She currently has a small commercial space and two public telephones (One-Cell). According to Ilda, the business is contributing positively to her family’s needs since she is able to help her husband in supporting the children and covering the household expenses. She currently works with one of her daughters and one employee. With the help of the loan, she was able to strengthen her business by increasing the volume of products and acquiring one additional public telephone.

Her business has had a positive impact on the community by providing communication services and essential products, thereby reducing the distances traveled to obtain these services. In the future, she plans to build a shop and a beauty salon and become a successful businesswoman, creating jobs for others.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização: Bairro Guachene- Catembe
Cliente: Ilda Leonor paulo M.
Actividade : Comércio
Valor de Empréstimo: 10.000,00mt (400.00US$)
Aplicação: compra de Produtos para revenda
Início: 16/08/2007
Fim: 07/11/ 2008

Ilda Leonor paulo M. , nasceu em Maputo em 1966, estudou até 7ªclasse isto porque perdeu o pai muito cedo tendo ficado a viver com a mãe e esta não tinha condições para custear os estudos dos filhos uma vez que era desempregada. Aos 18 anos juntou-se com seu marido com qual tem 5 filhos. Tentou trabalhar como empregada doméstica e não aguentou , tendo iniciado o seu pequeno negócio já com 19 anos, actividade esta que desenvolve até então.

Possui neste momento um pequeno estabelecimento comercial e dois telefones públicos ( one-cell) segundo ela , o negócio está contribuir positivamente no aumento da renda familiar uma vez que consegue ajudar o seu marido no sustento dos filhos e nas despesas da família , actualmente trabalha com uma das filhas e um empregado. Com o crédito reforçou o seu negócio aumentando o volume de produtos e a dquiriu mais um telefone público.

A sua actividade tem um impacto positivo na comunidade pelo facto de estar a providenciar serviços de comunicação e produtos de primeira necessidade, reduzindo a distâncias anteriorimente percorridas em busca dos mesmos serviços Futuramente pretende construir uma loja e um salão de beleza e tornar se numa grande comerciante e criar postos de trabalho para outros.

loans.use: To increase stocks in her business

loans.name: Juana Isabel

texts.es:
For 4 years Juana has belonged to the Communal Bank "La Amistad." Her home is located in Jr. Huancayo Mz. A Lte. 4 AA.HH Nuevo Bolognesi, Callería District, Ucayali State. She is 34 years old and she is a single mother to one daughter.

Today she raises 300 guinea pigs, 20 sheep, and 34 chickens at her house.

With the current loan from Manuela Ramos of 2000 soles (approximately US$667), which she will repay in 5 months, she will buy primarily nutritionally balanced food, vaccines, and will build pens for the animals she raises.

Juana feels very moved and thankful because she can perform the roles of both father and mother to her little girl and as a woman she feels satisfied in her personal development.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Juana pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Amistad” desde hace 4 años, su vivienda esta ubicada en el Jr. Huancayo Mz. A Lte. 4 AA.HH Nuevo Bolognesi, del Distrito de Callería del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 34 años y es madre de 1 niña, es madre soltera.

En la actualidad se dedica a la crianza de cuyes (300 unid.), carneros (20 unid.) y gallinas(34 unid.) los cría en su casa.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 2,000 (US$ 667.00 aprox.), que lo pagará en 5 meses, comprará alimentos balanceados al por mayor, comprará vacunas e implementará los corrales para los animales que cría.

Juana se siente muy emocionada y agradecida porque puede desempeñarse como padre y madre para su bebita y como mujer porque se siente satisfecha en su desarrollo personal.

loans.use: Purchase food and vaccines, and build animal pens.

loans.name: Vailety

texts.en:
This is 27-year-old Vailety, who runs a funky clothes shop in Kinondoni, ten minutes from downtown Dar es Salaam. This is one of the real hubs of Dar, a place where you walk down the main street and see the latest street fashion and mobile phone shops, along with truck stations and hole-in-the-wall eateries, all the while listening simultaneously to hip-hop music blasting from who-knows-where and haunting chants from the mosques calling people to prayer.

Vailety started the business in 2005 and requires a loan of US$ 700 to purchase additional stock. The business supports her and her one-year-old son Daudi (David).

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback arrangement as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and they are therefore termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory for her clothes shop

loans.name: Ashurov

texts.en:
Ashurov R. lives in Nausky rayon; he is married and has 4 children.  Ashurov R. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2006 and he recommended himself as a serious and strongly-motivated client.  Loan sums are continually increased, which shows business stability and income increase.  

Mr.Ashurov is very experienced in his business (about 15 years).  He is a driver in the PLC “Nonpaz” by professional background.  He has a wide business including livestock raising and selling, milk production and work out.  He dreams to purchase a horn pedigree bull and milk cow for further meat and sour-milk goods production (he supplies it to the bazaars).  It is planned to include in the assortment the following milk and sour-milk products: pasteurized milk, sour milk, sour cream, curd, etc. 

Now Mr.Ashurov requests a loan of $1050 for a horn pedigree bull and pedigree milk cow purchase, which will allow him to significantly increase the family income and plan further business development and assortment widening.

loans.use: For the purchase of a horn pedigree bull and pedigree milk cow

loans.name: Sutinah

texts.en: Sutinah, 47, is married to W. who does not have a fixed job. They have 2 daughters, aged 13 and 8. So to earn income for the family, she sells snacks and flavoured ice at her small stall in front of her house, earning about $10 a day with a very small profit margin. Now she is asking for a loan of $125 to buy more goods for her stall so she will be able to increase her income. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her stall

loans.name: Arturo

texts.es:
For Arturo, it all began with his move to one of the new districts in Lima, Carabayllo. When he arrived to set up home in the area, few people lived there, and therefore business was at a minimum. Seeing that so many of his neighbours, just like him, had to walk quite a way before finding any shops, he decided to open up his own small shop. Little by little, and with a lot of hard work, Arturo improved his shop and invested in it until he was able to supply groceries, fruit and veg. He confirms that it was very hard to start with, and accessing his house was difficult for suppliers. And so he had to carry goods from the road to his house. But he chose not to give up despite this problem, he felt that the advantages of the business were not only for him but also for the community. Today, in addition to running his store, construction of his drinks area is in progress.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

Para Arturo todo empezó con su mudanza a uno de los nuevos distritos de Lima, Carabayllo. Cuando él llegó a vivir en esta zona, los habitantes eran muy pocos, por ello, la presencia de comercio era mínima. Al ver que tanto sus vecinos como él debían caminar varias cuadras antes de encontrar una tienda, se animo a poner una pequeña. Fue así que poco a poco y con mucho esfuerzo Arturo fue mejorando su tienda e invirtiendo en ella hasta abastecerla de abarrotes, frutas y verduras. El afirma que le fue muy difícil al inicio, ya que el acceso a su casa no era muy fácil para los proveedores. Entonces el debía cargar la mercadería desde la carretera hasta su casa. Pero él no desistió al ver este problema, pues el sentía que la ganancia no solo era para el sino que también para la comunidad. En la actualidad, además de manejar su bodega, la construcción de su distribuidora de gas y cerveza está en camino.

loans.use: To invest in his new project, selling fizzy drinks and beer.

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
Juan Ramón T. is a 23-year-old enterprising young man, who is married and lives with his wife and parents. Juan works tailoring and silk-screening school and sports attire.

He opened his business in 2006, after gaining a great deal of experience thanks to the fact that he had been working for a company in this field for many years. Thanks to those years of apprenticeship and saving money, he now works for himself.

Juan says that at a young age, he started working to help his parents with the household expenses. Today, his entire family supports and helps him with the business. His parents are very proud of the great man that he has become, despite his young age. Juan would like to keep expanding his business. He plans to purchase an industrial sewing machine, which will allow him to increase production and fulfill his customers’ orders more speedily.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Juan Ramón T. es un joven emprendedor de 23 años, el esta casado, y vive con su señora en una casa junto con sus padres. Juan se dedica a la confección y serigrafía de atuendos deportivos y escolares.

Desde el año 2006, abrió su propio negocio luego de adquirir mucha experiencia gracias a que trabajo varios años en una empresa que se dedicaba a dicho ramo. Gracias a esos años de aprendizaje y ahorro el hoy día ya trabaja por su cuenta.

Juan dice que desde muy joven empezó a trabajar para ayudar a sus padres con los ingresos de la casa. Hoy toda su familia lo apoya y ayuda con el negocio, sus padres están muy orgullosos del gran hombre que es, a pesar de su corta edad. Juan desea seguir ampliando su negocio, y tiene pensado adquirir una maquina de coser industrial que le permitirá aumentar su producción y cumplir con los pedidos de todos sus clientes con mayor rapidez.

loans.use: Purchase of sewing machine

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha T. is a farmer and grocer in Makak village. In order to make her rice plantation produce a better crop, she has asked for a loan, partly to buy fertilizer and insecticide for her field and partly to pay for laborers who will help her working her rice field.

Mrs. Sokha T. is 44 and lives in Kampong Speu Province. She is married with six children, two of whom are working in a garment factory while another is cutting bamboo to sell for a profit. The rest are attending school. Her husband, Chhom Cheam, is a farmer and bamboo cutter. Mrs. Sokha T. already obtained a loan from AMK to buy pigs for breeding.

Last year her children got dengue fever and Mrs. Sokha T. spent a lot of money to have them healed. That’s why she is now short of money to buy supplies to improve her rice field. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and insecticide for her field and partly to pay for laborers

loans.name: Khanifa

texts.en: B. Khanifa is 57 years old. She is a widow and raised five children by herself. Thanks to Khanifa's effort, all of her children are married and have their own children now. Khanifa earns income selling make-up and cosmetics. She has been running her business already for ten years. Initially, Khanifa started it, because she did not have a job and needed to find a way to support her large family, being its only bread-winner. Khanifa is hoping to expand her business, to open her own store, and to establish constant supplies from well-known producers. Khanifa also dreams of having sufficient income to be able to provide her grand-children with good education, so that they one day become highly-demanded experts in their profession. Therefore, Khanifa is asking for a loan of US$600 in order to purchase a larger variety of make-up (lipsticks, mascaras, powder, skin cream, etc.) for sale. Khanifa would like to thank everybody for supporting her and promises to repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of perfumes, beauty products, clothing and other goods for a small general store.

loans.name: Frida's Faraja Group

texts.en:
Frida is 34 years old. She is a married woman with 4 children aged 16, 13, 9 and 2. She has owned and run a mill machine since 1995. She works everyday from 8am to 5.30pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Frida requests a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with food, shopkeeping and clothing and charcoal.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Marie Claire

texts.en:
Greetings from Marie Claire in Gisenyi town. Claire is 34 years old, married with 5 children and 1 adopted child. 

Claire sells second-hand clothes in Gisenyi market. She buys the clothes in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, and sells them in local markets in Gisenyi. She earns about US$ 125 per month. She employs one person to help her run the business.

She is looking for a loan worth 502,265 Frws to increase her stock.

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es:
Guadalupe inició el negocio por que anteriormente trabajaba en este mismo giro atendiendo una papelería de una señora y como le gustaba poco a poco fue reuniendo el capital suficiente para independizarse y poner su propio negocio. Comenzó hace aproximadamente 2 años primero manejaba solo mercería pero poco a poco fue agregando lo que es papelería primero lo mas común que pedían para las tareas de las escuelas como son mapas, estampas hojas de maquina libretas lápiz plumas etc. Y logro ampliarse y tener una gran variedad de productos.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $375 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar una copiadora y surtir algo de mercancía ya que como vive cerca de una escuela le piden seguido y en la colonia no hay por lo que es una buena oportunidad para ofrecer otro servicio.
texts.en:
Guadalupe started her own business because she previously worked in this branch, running a stationery store for a woman. Because she liked her job, she started saving money little by little so that she could become independent and set up her own business. She started approximately 2 years ago, selling only sewing notions. Little by little, she started adding school supplies such as maps, rubber stamps, printer paper, notebooks, pens, pencils, etc. She managed to expand and now offers a great variety of products.

She needs a loan of $375.00 USD, which she will repay in 3 months, so that she can purchase a copy machine and some merchandise. Since she lives near a school, customers ask for copy services. However, copy services are not offered in the residential area, which is why she sees it as a good opportunity to start offering these services.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase copy machine

loans.name: Vuoch

texts.en: Mrs. Vuoch L. lives in Spork Reach Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a pig breeder who raises twelve pigs. Her husband, Mr. Liv Bunla, is a taxi driver who can generate a small income to support his family. Although Mrs. Vuoch L. and her husband both have businesses, they still cannot afford to buy a piece of land to keep and then re-sell later. Thus, Mrs. Vuoch L. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Mrs. Vuoch L. is 38 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school, while the youngest one is five years old and too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land to keep and re-sell later at a better price.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard O. is 46 years old and married with four children. Richard is a baker by trade. He bakes meat pies and distributes to schools around his community. Richard has problems with the local oven he uses to bake, so he needs an electrical oven for baking to enable him to meet the demands of his customers. He needs the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase an electrical oven to bake more meat pies to sell. He says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase an electrical oven to bake more meat pies to sell

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is 35 years old and married with 3 children. She sells second-hand clothes to people who cannot currently afford new clothes. She started this business in 2007. She is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more second-hand clothes to sell. She says "thank you" to all of the people who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: 8 De Setiembre Group

texts.en:
The 8 D. Septiembre Village Bank is beginning its sixth loan cycle with 19 group members. The group members live in the Acosvinchos District, a farming community located 90 minutes outsiD. of the city of Ayacucho.  The group members have a variety of businesses. Some sell firewood, dry goods, grains, shoes, meat, clothing, and animals; others work as carpenters or bake bread.  They sell their wares from home, on the street and in the city of Ayacucho.  Isabel is 31 years old and is married with two children. Isabel has a dry goods store in her home, and she and her husband also make terra cotta roof tiles, which they also sell from home. Isabel needs a loan of 600 soles to buy rice and sugar.  Juana is 36 years old and is married with four children. Juana buys grains from different local producers. After buying a truckload full of grains, she brings it to the city of Ayacucho to sell. Juana also has a farm. She needs a loan of 600 soles to buy wheat and corn.  Aurora is 39 years old and is married with four children. Aurora sells meat. She buys the animals in nearby villages, slaughters them herself, and sells the meat in the local market. Aurora and her husband also sell sandals maD. from car tires, which are commonly worn by people who live in the countrysiD.. Aurora needs a loan of 300 soles to buy more of these sandals.  The group members are requesting different loan amounts, like 300, 450, 600, 900 or 1000 Peruvian Soles. These loans will be used to buy sandals, wheat, flour, sugar, sneakers, clothing, and to pay farmhands.  The group members dream that their children will grow up to be working professionals, of improving their businesses, and of having more investment capital. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

El Banco Comunal 8 D. Setiembre inicia su sexto ciclo con 19 socias, las socias viven en el distrito D. Acosvinchos que se ubica a 90 minutos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, donD. la población se dedica a la agricultura.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. leña, abarrotes en general, cereales, elaboración D. panes, calzados, carne, ropa, venta D. animales y brindan servicios D. carpintería. Sus ventas los realizan en sus domicilios, ambulantemente y también lo llevan a la ciudad D. Ayacucho. 
Como es el caso D. Isabel que es casada, tiene 31 años y 2 hijos, Isabel tiene una tienda D. abarrotes en su casa, también junto a su esposo se dedican a la fabricación D. tejas que venden en el mismo lugar. Isabel necesita un préstamo D. 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. arroz y azúcar. 
Por otro lado Juana es casada, tiene 36 años y 4 hijos, Juana compra cereales D. los diferentes pueblos luego D. acopiar los transporta a la ciudad D. Ayacucho en donD. lo comercializa, Juana también se dedica a la agricultura. Juana necesita un préstamo D. 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. trigo, maíz. 
Mientras que Aurora es casada, tiene 39 años y 4 hijos, Aurora venD. carne, los animales los compra D. los pueblos los benéfica y venD. en la feria D. su distrito. Además Aurora junto a su esposo venden ojotas. Aurora necesita un préstamo D. 300 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. ojotas. 
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 300 soles, 450 soles, 600 soles, 900 soles, 1000 soles haciendo un total D. 10,200 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal.
Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra D. ojotas, trigo, maíz, harina, azúcar, arroz, zapatillas, ropa y para el pago D. los peones. 
Los sueños D. las socias son que sus hijos sean profesionales, mejorar sus negocios, tener mas capital.

loans.use: Buying sandals, wheat, flour, sugar, sneakers, clothing, and to pay farmhands.

loans.name: Husna

texts.en:
Husna has been selling clothes and charcoal in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $25. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and charcoal for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business.

Husna is 23 years old, married, and has two children aged 1 and 4.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and charcoal to expand her business.

loans.name: Janet

texts.es:
Janet se dedica a la venta de perfumes y cosméticos, y es la única que genera ingresos ya que esta separada de su esposo.
Vive en la zona de Villa San Antonio Bajo de la Ciudad de La Paz, en alquiler 
El crédito será destinado para capital de trabajo ( compra de perfumes y cosméticos), para continuar con su negocio y obtener mejores ingresos.
Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, con este crédito tendrá la oportunidad de mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Janet dedicates herself to the sale of perfumes and cosmetics. She is the only one that generates income because she is separated from her husband. She rents her home which is located in the Villa San Antonio Bajo zone in the city of La Paz. The loan she is requesting will be used as working capital to purchase perfumes and cosmetics to carry on her business and obtain better profits. This is the first time Janet requests a loan from IMPRO. With this loan she will have the opportunity to improve her living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more perfumes and cosmetics for resale in her business.

loans.name: Sofía

texts.es: Sofía a sus 58 años ha pasado por muchos sacrificios para mantener a sus dos hijos, Cesar de 21 y Bernardo de 19. A lo largo de su vida ha trabajado mucho para poder brindarle a su familia las comodidades necesarias, actualmente está en el negocio de la venta de manualidades, realiza muñequitos, manteles, adornos, etc, de tela y los lleva a vender en su puesto ubicado en el centro de la ciudad de Puno, al cual concurren todos sus clientes en busca de algo bonito y novedoso para ocasiones especiales. A Sofía le gusta mucho trabajar con tela y crear muñequitos y adornos decorativos, aunque le es difícil y demora armar sus manualidades parte por parte, en espera de que le queden muy bien. Lleva ya 10 años realizando esta actividad y desea que en el futuro su puesto de venta crezca y se convierta en una de las principales tiendas de la ciudad, donde pueda tener más clientes y mejorar sus ingresos para darle una vida más digna a su familia. Es el primer préstamo de Sofía con MFP y tiene mucha confianza en que podrá pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, en su banco comunal es muy tranquila y disfruta de trabajar en equipo con el resto de sus socias. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de los materiales necesarios para la fabricación de sus manualidades.
texts.en:
Sofia, 58, has gone through a lot of sacrifices to take care of her two sons, 21-year-old Cesar and 19-year-old Bernardo. Throughout her life she's worked hard to be able to offer her family all the necessary comforts. Currently she's in the business of selling handicrafts. She makes dolls, tablecloths, ornaments, etc., using fabric. She then takes them to sell in her stand located in downtown Puno, where all her customers converge in search of some pretty and original thing for special occasions. Sofia likes to work with fabric and to create dolls and decorative ornaments, though it's difficult for her and takes her a while to assemble her crafts piece by piece, in hopes that they turn out well. She's been carrying out this craftwork for ten years now, and she hopes to have more customers in the future and to improve her earnings to give a more dignified life to her family.

This is Sofia's first loan with MFP, and she's very confident that she'll be able to pay back all payments on time. She's very content with her communal bank and enjoys working as a team with the rest of her partners. With the requested money she'll buy a greater quantity of materials required to make her crafts.

Translated from Spanish by Todd Schmid, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de materiales para sus artesanías

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
Ailyn C., 25, is a resident of Bacolod Ozamiz City. She runs a barbecue business. Together with her husband, who is a hard working farmer, they started their business with a small amount of capital. They have set up of a table at Bacolod Ozamiz City, at the road side. Now they have more customers to serve with the help of her husband.

Recently, Ailyn requested a loan of Php 1,500 as additional capital to purchase meat and ingredients for her barbecue business. Ailyn's future plan for her family is to expand her business and build her own house, since she living with her parents.

loans.use: Purchase additional meat for her B-B-Q business.

loans.name: Cinforiana

texts.es: Cinforiana de 43 años, es una madre de familia muy amorosa, vive en una pequeña casa, la cual ella misma construyó con sus propias manos, lo que más quiere, es brindarle a sus 2 queridos hijos Luz de 22 y Dennis de 17 años, unos buenos estudios, para que en el futuro puedan salir adelante por sí solos. Los 15 años que Cinforiana viene realizando la crianza de ganado, le han servido para forjarse una vida digna, realiza esta actividad desde que tenia 15 años y actualmente se ha convertido en una de las ganaderas más reconocidas, debido a las grandes reses que lleva a vender a la ciudad de Juliaca. Cinforiana es natural del distrito de Taraco (Distrito de la Provincia de Huancane) y lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es criar su ganado, ya que sabe que mientras mejor los cuide, mejores pagos le darán por sus reses, pero lo más difícil para ella, es transportarlo al lugar de la venta, puesto que es una actividad que le demanda mucho tiempo y esfuerzo. Para el futuro desea tener una tienda de abarrotes, la cual le pueda generar otros ingresos y así mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. Este es el primer préstamo de Cinforiana con MFP, se siente en la responsabilidad de pagarlo a tiempo, puesto que no quiere meter en problemas a las socias de su banco comunal, en donde es muy querida debido a la alegría que le pone a las reuniones. Invertirá los setecientos nuevos que solicita en comprar una vaca, la cual le costara alrededor de tres mil nuevos soles, para ello está dispuesta a poner dinero de sus ahorros, con tal de aumentar el número de sus reses que tiene.
texts.en:
Cinforiana is 43 years old, and is the mother of a beautiful family. She lives in a small house that she built with her own hands. What she wants most is to provide her 2 beloved children Luz (22 years old) and Dennis (17 years old) with a good education so that they can make it on their own in the future. Cinforiana has raised cattle for 15 years now, and this activity has allowed her to make a decent living. She has been involved in this line of work since she was 15 years old, and she is now one of the most famous livestock farmers in her area because of the large animals she takes to sell in the city of Juliaca. Cinforiana is from the Taraco district (a district in the province of Huancane). What she likes most about her work is raising her cattle, since she knows that the more she looks after her animals, the better the price she’ll get for them. However, it’s quite difficult for her to transport them to market, since that’s a task that requires much time and effort. In the future she would like to have a grocery store, which would allow her to generate additional income and improve her family’s quality of life. This is Cinforiana’s first loan with Kiva partner MFP, and she understands the responsibility of making payments on time, since she doesn’t want to cause any problems with her colleagues at the communal bank, where she is well liked because of the joy she brings to meetings. She will invest the 700 soles she is requesting in purchasing a cow. The cow will cost her around 3000 soles, and Cinforiana is planning to supplement the loan with money from her savings to pay for it. Her hope is to increase the number of animals she has.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a cow

loans.name: Jeaneth Del Carmen

texts.es: La Señora. Janeth Gutiérrez tiene 39 años de edad,  casada con dos hijos, se desempeña como conserje en una empresa gubernamental desde hace seis años. Unos de sus proyectos es la construcción de su vivienda, alcanzar un mejor nivel de vida para el bienestar de sus hijos. Requiere de la construcción de un cuarto para brindarle seguridad y protección. Las dificultares que tiene es la falta de financiamientos. Gracias al préstamo en Afodenic lograra iniciar con su proyecto comprando materiales como: cemento, arena, piedrines, zinc, reglones de madera, perlines. Con esto espera estar en mejores condiciones.
texts.en:
Janeth Gutiérrez is 39 years old, married, and has two children. She has worked as a caretaker at a government enterprise for the past six years. One of her projects is the building of her house, in order to reach a better standard of living and provide well-being for her children. She requires the construction of a room to provide security and protection. The difficulty she is encountering is lack of financing. Thanks to the loan with Afodenic, she will manage to start her project by buying materials such as: cement, sand, stones, zinc, lumber, beams. With this project, she hopes to improve her living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials to make improvements to her dwelling.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene P. is from the town of Taguima, in Tudela, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is 49 years old. Irene is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Irene owns and operates general store where she sells both food and daily-use products in the local community. Irene has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from her business

In 2005, Irene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services and to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC, which she used to to purchase additional inventory. Irene is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be the ninth loan that Irene has taken from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use for working capital

loans.name: Mirna

texts.es:
MIRNA G. P., pertenece al Banco Comunal “LAS NAZARENAS vive en el Distrito de Camporverde, tiene 45 años, 5 hijos de los cuáles dos de ellos menores y su esposo es agricultor.

El primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos fue de S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual lo invirtió en gaseosas para venderlo en una fuente de soda.

Con este préstamo de S/.1,700.00 Nuevos Soles lo invertiirá en la compra de msesas, sillas, gaseosas y otros productos que servirán para mejorar su pequeño local.

Agradece a Manuela Ramos por los 4 años que viene trabajando con ella ya que le ha permitido implementar su negocio y el cual la ha ayudado a salir a adelante como empresaria. Manifiesta que hoy más que nunca se siente capaz de administrar su propio negocio.
texts.en:
Mirna G. P. belongs to the “Las Nazarenas” community bank. She lives in the Camporverde district, is 45 years old, and has five children of which two are young. Her husband is in agriculture.

The first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos was for 300.00 Nuevos Soles, which she invested in sodas to sell from a soda fountain.

With this loan of 1,700.00 Nuevos Soles, she will buy tables, chairs, sodas and other products that will serve to improve her small business.

She thanks Manuela Ramos for the 4 years working together with her, which has allowed her to start her business and move forward as a businesswoman. It shows that today, more than ever, she feels the capacity to run her own business.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tables, chairs, sodas and other products for her soda fountain

loans.name: Mansu

texts.en:
Mansu S. is a resident of Sainbu-Bhaishipati. Sainbu-Bhaishipati is located in Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are engaged in agriculture.

Mrs. S. lives in a single family with her husband, Mr. Utam S., and two sons. Her husband went to foreign country to work. Her older son is studying in grade 5 and younger son is studying in grade 4.

Mrs. S. opened a small food shop three years ago to improve the economic condition of her family. She sells a variety of food items in her shop, including Nepali food such as dalbhat (rice). She also serves tea and coffee to the customers. The demand for food in her town is increasing. Therefore, Mrs. S. is requesting a loan of 15000 NPR to buy ingredients to produce more food.

loans.use: To buy food materials for her work.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia is 41 years old. She is married and the mother of three children. All her children have finished the junior high school and have yet to continue to the senior high school. She is a trader and a dealer of used bags (both traveling and dressing bags). She has a good selection, matching the brand new ones they sell in the market. For that reason, she has widened her market share and has call for increments in demand. She is therefore appealing for your assistance to realize her dream of making more profits to aid in her children's future (education). With the loan, she wants to buy more from the importers to upgrade her stock. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy a supply of used bags for retail

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard W. is 29 years old. He is married and the father of a daughter named Trizah. He lives in Mikindani, Mombasa where he runs a store that sells electronics and mobile accessories. His business has been in operation for 8 years. 

This will be Bernard's first loan from KADET. He plans to use the money to increase his stock of electrical ware and to purchase a computer for mobile repairs.

In the future. Bernard hopes to open more stores in Mikindani and to expand further into other towns.

loans.use: To increase his stock of electrical ware and to buy a computer

loans.name: Juan Fidel

texts.es: Don Juanito como es conocido en su comunidad su actividad principal es la carpinteria el es originario de la comunidad de Chimente a 42 kilometros del municipio de Totonicapan una comunidad muy abandonado por los gobiernos locales y centrales el trata la manera de sobre salir para poder mantener su familia el ha visitado varias organizaciones en el departamento del Quiche que esta quince kilometros  pero como son originario del departamento de Totonicapan no se ha consedio prestamo el visita las oficina de ASDIR para un credito que lo invertira en la compra de madera y herramienta.
texts.en:
Don Juanito, as he is known in his community, makes carpentry his principal activity. He is originally from Chimente, 42 kilometers from the municipality of Totonicapan, a community very neglected by the local and central governments. In this way, he tries to support his family.

He has visited various organizations in the state of Quiche, which is 15 kilometers away, but since he and his family are originally from the state of Totonicapan, he has not been able to obtain a loan. He visits the ASDIR offices for a loan to invest in the purchase of wood and tools.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick Clarke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase in Capital

loans.name: David 5,6 Group

texts.en:
Arsina shares a home with at least five other family members. They live in a wooden house with a tin roof and no electricity, running water or telephone service, but all of his children currently attend the local public school. The family lives in La Romana, an area on the southeast coast of the Dominican Republic.

Despite his lack of formal education, Arsina recently began using his skills and resources to start earning a regular income through his "motoconcho" service. A motoconcho is a small motorcycle used to give people rides around town.

Arsina became an associate of Esperanza International, has successfully completed two loan cycles and is looking to start his third. With this loan he is planning on buying a new motor for his motoconcho so that he can make enough money to give his family three meals a day and ensure that his children can finish their education. Arsina would like to thank all donors for their support.

loans.use: To buy a new motor for his motoconcho

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.en: Gulnara is single and lives in Baku city. She was born in 1986. Four years ago she started her clothing sales business. Now she needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy more clothes and shoes to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Abieyuwa

texts.en: Abieyuwa sells frozen foods like turkey, chicken and fish within her community in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She is 36 years old, married, and has no children. She has been in this business for 6 years. She is applying for a loan of N150,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She would like to thank all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji S. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste, tomatoes, etc. and is requesting a loan to purchase onions and cooking oil to sell. Keji is 35 years old and married to a nurse. They have six children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Adolfo

texts.es:
Adolfo, de 51 años, es un hombre muy trabajador, vive en la casa de sus familiares junto a su esposa, a quien desea dar una buena vida.

Él se dedica es la panadería, su labor comienza muy temprano, aproximadamente a las 4:30 de la mañana ya está en pie y listo para amasar y hacer los panes que disfruta todo su barrio. 
Adolfo es un panadero muy hábil y es que desde muy pequeño aprendió este oficio de su padre.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es hacer los panes y lo hace con mucho esmero, lleva 30 años en este trabajo y considera que lo más difícil es tener que levantarse todos los días temprano, ya que para él no existen fines de semana, ni feriados. 
Para más adelante, anhela poner una tienda donde pueda vender el mismo los panes que hornea.

Este es el primer préstamo de Adolfo con MFP y no quiere dejar de pagarlo por falta de dinero, así que está dispuesto a ahorrar día a día para poder pagarlo. Además es muy responsable y respetuoso con las demás socias. Con los mil soles solicitados comprará nuevas bandejas y estantes para los panes, además hará arreglar su horno.
texts.en:
Adolfo, 51, is a hard-working man who lives in his relatives' house with his wife, for whom he wants to provide a good life. He is a baker. His workday begins very early in the morning, at about 4:30am, when he gets up to start kneading the dough and making the bread which everyone in the neighborhood enjoys. Adolfo is a very skilled baker because he learned the craft as a little boy from his father. What he most likes about the job is baking bread which he does with great care. He has had this occupation for 30 years and he considers the most difficult part having to get up so early in the morning every day since for him there is no such thing as weekends or holidays. For later in the future, he would like to set up a store to sell the bread that he himself bakes. This is his first loan with MFP and he doesn't want to fail to repay it for lack of money so he is willing to save day by day to repay it. Besides, he is very responsible and respectful toward the other members. With the one-thousand soles requested he will buy new baking sheets and stands for his bread and he will also get his oven repaired.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy utensils.

loans.name: Tserendolgor

texts.en:
G. Tserendolgor is 49 years old and lives with his wife in Uvurhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. He and his wife have one daughter and she is 26 years old and lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. G. owns a motorcycle which he uses as a taxi at the local market. Since his motorcycle is cheaper than a taxicab, those who are going home from the market with bags of stuff like to use his motorcycle. When he has more time, he also retails cattle skins and sheepskins. He purchases animal skins from the herder families and resells them at the market for a profit. G.'s wife makes traditional clothes at home. She is a talented sewer and has been making traditional clothes for locals for many years. G. says that he works hard with his wife to send some money for their only daughter who lives in the capital city. They want her to purchase her own piece of land where she can reside in the city. G. requests a loan to purchase more animal skins for his business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more animal skins to sell

loans.name: Ganchimeg

texts.en:
Ganchimeg is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in a wooden house in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her two daughters, aged 10 and 6, both attend a local secondary school while her husband operates a taxi service in town.

Ganchimeg operates a grocery shop near her home which she inherited from her mother. When the business began, her mother operated out of a small booth which was passed down to Ganchimeg. Since getting the business in 2002, Ganchimeg has successfully expanded it and grown it into a full shop. Now, she not only sells grocery items, but also coal and firewood which are used as fuels in order to heat her customers’ homes.

Currently Ganchimeg earns between 400,000 and 500,000 tugrugs (~280-350 USD) per month and attributes her business success to her good accounting skills.

Ganchimeg would like to keep expanding her shop in the future and is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of food supplies, coal and firewood for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of food supplies, coal and firewood

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Madame Aminata G. est couturière depuis 1980.Elle a 49 ans, elle habite dans la cite Apecsy a Yoff. Elle est sociétaire de la caisse d’U-IMCEC Yoff depuis juin 2000.Elle est marie et mère de 4 enfants  dont l’âge varie entre 19 et 28 ans. Elle a aussi 4 personnes à sa charge. En même temps Madame G. s’adonne au commerce d’habits confectionnes.
Elle a héritai l’activiste de couturière de ses parents, sa maman était une grande couturière et c’était presque un don chez elles. Ce qui l’intéresse le plus dans son activité c’est la satisfaction des clients de par son esprit créatif. C’est une grande styliste.  Elle a déjà rembourse 2 crédits dans l’institution. Maintenant elle sollicite un prêt de 150 000 frs dans le but d’acheter des tissus bazin, voile et aussi des garnitures pour la confection d’autres habits a vendre. Ainsi elle pourra renouveler son exposition. Les bénéfices réalises lui  permettent de maintenir et d’augmenter sa participation dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  à exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique  apprécié.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aminata G. has been a seamstress since 1980. She's 49 years old, and lives in Apecsy city in Yoff. She's been a member of the U-IMCEC savings group since June 2000. She's married and the mother of four children, age 19 to 28. She also has four persons to support. At the same time, Mrs. G. also sells clothing. She inherited this activity from her parents, her mother was a great seamstress and it's almost a gift to them. What she finds most interesting in her business is satisfying her clients through her creative mind. She's a great stylist.

She already repaid two loans from U-IMCEC and she's now seeking a loan to buy Bazin and veil fabrics, as well as accessories for other clothing she sells. This will enable her to renew her display. The profits enable her to maintain and increase her participation to the daily expenses.

Always looking to actively participate in the fight against poverty, U-IMCEC, with the support of lenders, succeeds in supporting populations in revenue-generating activities, which promotes valuable socio-economic development.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Bazin and veil fabrics, and clothing accessories

loans.name: Fortunita

texts.es:
Fortunita es socia del Banco Comunal Firmeza.
Fortunita es conviviente, tiene 41 años y 4 hijos, Fortunita junto a su esposo se dedican a la vende de chompas, bufandas, guantes, actividad que realiza de manera ambulatoria con un triciclo, sus productos los adquiere en la ciudad de Juliaca.
Fortunita necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de chompas.
Fortunita sueña con ampliar su casa y negocios.
texts.en:
Fortunita, 41, is a member of the Firmeza communal bank. She lives with her life partner and has 4 children. Together with her husband, Fortunita drives around in their three-wheeled vehicle selling jackets, mufflers and gloves; she gets her products in Juliaca. Fortunita needs a 2000 sol loan to buy jackets. Fortunita dreams with enlarging her home and her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy jackets.

loans.name: Maria Reveca

texts.es:
La Sra. María , tiene 41 años, vive en el Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martin , Departamento de San Martin , la socia  pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Flores de María II” , es casada ,  presenta estudios de secundaria completa  y tiene 04 hijos , 01  que aun estudia y depende de ella .

Maria, se dedica a la venta de Comidas Preparadas y lleva 10 años en el negocio, se encuentra ubicada en un puesto del Mercado Central, un lugar muy amplio y acondicionado para atender a sus clientes que diariamente acuden. Nos cuenta que a diario tiene muy buenas ventas,  es conocida y tiene muy buena acogida. Con su primer crédito de 500 Nuevos Soles, compró ingredientes para el preparado de sus comidas como, arroz en kilos, pollos en javas, plátanos en racimos, y parte del dinero lo invirtió en utensilios.  

En la actualidad, continúa con el mismo negocio y esta muy contenta con su trabajo que realiza día a día. Es ella quien personalmente atiende a sus clientes con el carisma y amabilidad que le caracteriza.

Con este crédito  de S/ 1,000.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará ingredientes para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos como, arroz en kilos, aceites en litros, pollos en javas, plátanos , maduros en racimos y también  algunos utensilios, para dar una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Marita como le dicen de cariño , se siente llena de vida y con ganas de seguir adelante, su sueño es tener un Minimarket  y implementar su propia tienda de bebidas gasificadas , muy bien acondicionado y al mismo tiempo también agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  en iniciar su negocio.
texts.en:
Maria is 41 years old and lives in the Tarapoto district, in the San Martin province in the San Martin department. She belongs to the communal bank “Las Flores de María II.” She is married, has completed her secondary education, and has 4 children, 1 who is still in school and dependent. Maria has been selling prepared meals from a place in the Central Market for 10 years. Her place is very large and is equipped to serve the customers who come daily. She tells us that she has very good sales each day; she is well-known, and is very welcoming to her customers. With her first loan of 500 Peruvian soles she bought ingredients to prepare her meals such as kilos of rice, crates of chicken, bunches of bananas and also utensils. Currently she will continue with the same business, and she is very content with the work she does every day. She personally attends to her customers with her characteristic friendliness and charm. With this loan of 1,000 Peruvian soles she will buy ingredients for the preparation of her meals such as kilos of rice, liters of cooking oil, crates of chicken, bunches of ripe bananas and also some utensils, so that she can better serve her customers. Marita, as they refer to her fondly, feels full of life and has a strong desire to succeed. Her dream is to have a Minimarket, to set up her own well-equipped store selling soft drinks. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movimiento organization for helping her to start her business.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: she will buy ingredients for the preparation of her meals

loans.name: Laura Fariñas Group

texts.en:
Laura F. is from the town of Tinang, Concepcion. She is 32 years old. Laura is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Laura is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Laura owns & operates a business venture selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling personal and home products to tourists and local community members. Laura has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Laura joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laura has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Laura is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Laura from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
