María presidenta del grupo del Banco comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra sentada en primera fila, en el lugar de en medio, viste con una blusa estampada con colores blancos y negros, además usa una falda larga color negro. Su cabello lo usa corto y es de color castaño oscuro. 
Ella se dedica al rubro del comercio, específicamente atiende un local con venta de abarrotes y demás alimentos (cecinas, pan, bebidas, confites). Trabaja de lunes a domingo de 7ºº de la mañana hasta las 10ºº de la noche, desde hace un año. Comenta que el sector donde vive existen pocos negocios, por lo que no existe competencia. 
Su mercadería la compra preferentemente en supermercados mayoristas y confiterías en el centro de la ciudad.
Con el crédito comprará mercadería para abastecer su negocio.
Sus metas son incorporar maquinarias que faciliten su trabajo, como pesa digital, cortadora de cecinas y una congeladora, además de contar con una mayor variedad de productos. 
María está muy contenta y agradecida de la oportunidad brindada por Fondo Esperanza, ya que le permitirá invertir en su negocio y probablemente le permita generar mayores ingresos. Comenta que disfruta mucho de las reuniones, ya que el grupo del Banco comunal del cual forma parte es muy unido y comprometido.
Respecto a las capacitaciones, estas le permiten proyectarse en su negocio. 
Temuco es la capital de la región de la Araucanía. La ciudad se ubica a 670 kilómetros al sur de Santiago (capital de Chile). En sus alrededores se ubican una serie de balnearios lacustres (Pucón, Villarrica) y una flora y fauna nativa muy llamativas, concentrada en parques naturales cercanos. Cabe destacar que en esta región habita el 50% de los mapuches, pueblo indígena, existente en nuestro país.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Caminando Juntos” (Walking Together) and it’s made up of 18 entrepreneurs who are in a variety of lines of work among which we have mobile phone sales, lathe shop, clothes making, drape making, crafts, and firewood sales, among others.  They are all from the city of Temuco.

María is communal bank president and appears in the photo seated in the front row in the second spot in the middle and is wearing a black and white printed blouse and a long black skirt.  She wears her hair short and it’s dark brown.

She’s a merchant specifically a grocery and food seller (cecina [cured, dried meat], bread, beverages, and snacks).   She has worked for the last year from Monday to Sunday from 7 in the morning until 10 at night.  She comments that in the sector where she lives there are few businesses so there is no competition.  She prefers to buy her merchandise in wholesale supermarkets and sweetshops in the center of the city.  She will use the loan to buy merchandise to stock her store.  Her goal is to incorporate machinery that will ease her work like a digital scale, a meat slicer and a freezer as well as to have a wider variety of products.

María is very happy and grateful for the opportunity Fondo Esperanza is providing her because it will make it possible for her to invest in her business and possibly allow her to generate higher income.  She comments that she enjoys the meetings very much because the communal bank she’s part of is very united and committed.  With respect to the training, it's allowed her to go forward in her business.

Temuco is the capital of the Araucanía region.  It’s located 670 kilometers south of Santiago (Capital of Chile).  In its surroundings are found lakeside resorts (Pucón, Villarrica) and very eye-catching flora and fauna concentrated in nearby natural parks.  It’s worth pointing out that 50% of the Mapuche population, indigenous people in our country, live here.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to stock her store.

loans.name: Naifa

texts.en: Naifa is a 55 year old married woman from Al Khaledieh, Al Mafraq, Jordan who hleps support 5 family members. She is requesting a loan of 600 JOD to buy fabric which she will sew into products such as clothes that she can sell. She is planning on renting a shop to sell her products. She hopes that this will help increase her income and living standard.

loans.use: to buy fabric for sewing

loans.name: Nurullo

texts.ru: Это Нурулло. Ему 30 лет. Он женат и имеет детей. Нурулло проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Он честный и талантливый человек. Нурулло занимается поваром в столовое. Он вкусно готовит.  У него есть свои клиенты, которые часто заходят, перекусит к нему столовое. Нурулло готовить картофель фри и разную пищу. Он берет кредит, чтобы расширить деятельность и привлечь больше клиентов. За счет кредита он хочет приобрести аппарат для приготовление пищи, и другие принадлежности. В дальнейшем Нурулло хочет стать хорошем поваром. Поддержите его достичь своих целей.
texts.en: Meet Nurullo, a 30-year-old husband and father.  Nurullo lives in the city of Tursunzoda.  He is honest and skilled.  He works as a cook in a casual restaurant and prepares delicious dishes.  Some of his customers frequently visit his restaurant for a quick meal.  Nurullo makes French fries and various other dishes.  He is taking a loan to expand his activity and to attract more customers.  He will use his loan to buy some food-preparation equipment and other accessories.  In the future, Nurullo wants to become a great cook.  Please support him and help him reach his goals.

loans.use: to buy food preparation equipment and other accessories.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Salome would like to add few cartons of palstic cups,bowls.and spoons

loans.name: Oswaldo

texts.en:
Oswaldo has been farming for 25 years and raising cattle for 30. He owns a small plot of land in Santa Lucia, Ecuador, where he cultivates rice and also has some livestock. Oswaldo and his wife Mersy have 2 children, ages 10 and 11. He hopes that with this loan he will be able to buy fertilizer for his rice, a resource he is particularly in need of. Although Oswaldo runs his farm well, he does not have a formal education and has very limited reading and writing skills. He believes his farm will continue to generate profits, especially with this loan, and he will be able to provide his children with the education he did not have the privilege of receiving himself.

The Primero de Agosto Communal Bank in Santa Lucia

Oswaldo is part of one of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program: the Primero de Agosto Communal Bank. All bank members are part of the Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia, and they will use these microloans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. As members of a communal bank, they are all guarantors for each other's loans. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about the commnity of Santa Lucia, compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The region is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area, as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with the rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them harvest their crop. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not have access to formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also often lack skills and knowledge of how to commercialize their product and get fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them to repay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Buy materials for rice farming

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa has a business selling fruits, such as apples, grapes, passion fruit, oranges, tree tomatoes, and others. She and her husband sell her products from a truck. She began in this business 12 years ago with her savings. Before this business, she had a small restaurant in the market. Because of renovations in the market, which were being done by the city, they lost their spot there. Rosa sells fruit on her route every day of the week from 6:00AM until 6:00PM.

Rosa needs more capital in order to buy more fruits. Her sales have increased and the working capital she has isn’t enough to allow her supply her business with more products.

Rosa is 43 years old and has one married daughter; she has no dependents. With the improvements the city was making, she also lost her land and her house. She was relocated to another piece of land in a different neighborhood of the island. Due to this situation, Rosa had to construct her house. This created expenses, and her working capital was reduced. Rosa has faith that with her loan, her income will increase and she will be able to continue improving her house, which still has a dirt floor.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosa tiene negocio de venta de frutas de manzanas, uvas, granadillas, naranjas, tomate de árbol y otros. Recorre sus productos en una camioneta junto con su esposo. Se inicio en este negocio desde hace 12 años con ahorros de ella. Anterior a este negocio tenía un comedor en mercado el mismo que por readecuación dada por municipio de la ciudad, tuvieron que ser desalojados. Rosa realiza su recorrido todos los días de la semana desde las 6: AM a 18: PM

Rosa necesita mas capital para poder invertirlo en comprar mas frutas. Sus ventas han aumentado y su capital no le permite poder surtirlo con más productos.

Rosa tiene 43 años 1 hija que ya esta casada y no depende de ella. Con las readecuaciones dada por municipio ella también perdió su terreno y vivienda. Rosa fue reubicada en otro terreno en sector diferente dentro de la isla. Con esta situación Rosa tubo que construir su vivienda y esto genero gastos y su capital se fue bajando. Rosa tiene la fe de que con el crédito sus ganancias se incrementaran y podrá dar algo de ellas para seguir adecuando su vivienda ya que aun su piso esta en tierra.

loans.use: To buy more fruit

loans.name: Ramos

texts.en:
For the last 12 years, Ramos C. has been weaving and selling her Mayan handicrafts in a village along the shore of Lake Atitlan in the Highlands of Guatemala. You can find this shy woman weaving a belt or a tablecloth every day at a stall along the road, which leads to and from the docks at the lake. She works hard in order to take care of her ten children, aged 3 to 23. At the age of 42, she and her husband dream of earning enough to feed, clothe and educate all ten of their children. She never had an educational opportunity and speaks mostly the local Mayan language, Cachiquel.

Ramos will be starting her ninth credit, with more than four years of successful repayment history. The credit she is requesting in this cycle will be used to buy materials and also to pay for some of the school expenses of her children.

The closest she has come to receiving an education is at the monthly meetings of her women’s credit group called “Santa Caterina”. Here she learns about managing a business, health care for herself and her family and gets to talk with other women. Ramos likes the meeting very much, but because of her diminished hearing, it is sometimes hard to understand all that is going on, and sometimes the meeting deals with subjects, which are far from her normal day to day life.

Before she took out her first loan she could only make one product at a time because she had to sell that one in order to buy material for the next. With her small credits she has been able to buy enough material to weave many and sell her hand-woven craft at her own stall along the road, which leads to and from the docks at the lake.

loans.use: The loan is to buy new material to be able to weave more.

loans.name: Jesus William

texts.es:
Jesús is an entreprenurial cattleman who, through hard work, has grown his capital little by little. He yearns to make his small business into a big family business so that he can improve the quality of life for his wife and children. He currently has 5 cows and grows his own feed for them, in order to improve the quality of the milk that they produce. His desire to grow has led him to improve his production techniques, so that he can distribute the milk to his clients in a timely manner.

Jesús wants to buy another cow to increase the amount of milk produced and gradually establish a store in his house where he will sell high-quality dairy products. In order to begin this project, Jesús is requesting a loan of $425.00, which he is committed to repaying over a period of 6 months. With your help, Jesús will be able to get another cow and improve the cattle’s feed. Let’s work together so that Jesús can make his dream a reality.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Jesús es un impetuoso ganadero que a través de su trabajo a ido incrementando poco a poco su capital y anhelo de hacer de su pequeño negocio una gran empresa familiar para mejorar la calidad de vida de sus hijos y esposa.Actualmente tiene 5 vacas y también se dedica a la siembra de pastizales para incrementar la calidad de la leche que producen sus queridas amigas. Su interés y deseo de crecer lo han llevado a tecnificar su producción para distribuirlo oportunamente a sus clientes. El deseo de Jesús es comprar una vaquita más para acrecentar la cantidad de leche y poder establecer paulatinamente en las instalaciones de su hogar una planta en la que ofrecería productos lácteos de excelente calidad.Para iniciar este proyecto, Jesús, solicita un préstamo de 425 dólares con el compromiso de retornarlos en un lapso de 6 meses. Con tu ayuda Jesús podrá adquirir una vaquita y mejorará el alimento que consumen a diario. Hagamos juntos que ese corazón soñador convierta en realidad sus anhelos.

loans.use: To buy a cow, which will bring Jesus closer to his dream of expanding his small business into a larger one

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Mrs. Neang K., aged 49, is a widow who works as a garment worker, earning about $4 per day. She has three children who are also garment workers. Her mother lives with her and her children. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a motorbike for her family’s transportation to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for herself and her children to commute to work at the garment factory.

loans.name: Tolibjon

texts.en: Tolibjon T. lives in Khujand; he is married and has 3 children. He is an experienced businessman, and the main sphere of his activity is livestock. He recommends himself as an honest and serious client. Having a lot of interesting and real ideas, now he requires a loan for business support and modernization, and to have the opportunity to realize the ideas in life.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: he needs the loan to purchase goods

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: Edith F. is a 24-year-old trader. She does not yet own her own trading stand, so she carries her goods around to various markets selling shoes and garments. She is married and has 1 young child.  She is requesting $525 to further expand her selection of shoes and garments so she can increase her income and reach more prospective clients.

loans.use: To further expand her selection of shoes and garments.

loans.name: Ndifakulya East D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jackline S.. She is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase a hair dryer. Jackline is 29 years old and is married. Her husband is a shop attendant. She has 2 children, aged 11 and 18, both of whom go to school. Each week, Jackline makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children.

Jackline is joined in her small group by Naster B., Jane N., Rehema K., and Grace K.. Naster B. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to expand to bulk selling. Jane N. is currently operating a business in poultry keeping and wants a loan to purchase poultry feed. Rehema K. operates a carpentry business and wants to purchase more timber. Grace K. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase more cloth fabric.

loans.use: To add to salon business

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok S. is 35 years old and runs a grocery store from her home in Prey Veng province. She makes 15 USD a day through this business. Her husband also helps to support Sok S. and their two children by working as a taxi driver in the capital of Phnom Penh. He makes 6 USD per day on average.

She wants to apply her loan towards building the family a more stable wooden home, from which she also hopes to expand her grocery store.

loans.use: To build a family home.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is forty three years old. He is married and he has been in the welding and fabrication business for ten years. He wants to use his loan to buy more scrap metal to manufacture coal pots, dustbins, dust trays, etc. He hopes that income from this loan will enable him to support his wife's venture to start working to earn additional income for the family.

He is a member of the group called “Nyame wo Tum” (meaning "God has power"). This photo of Isaac was taken during a group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more scrap metal for welding and fabrication

loans.name: Carlos Guillermo

texts.es:
Carlos Guillermo O., as the father and the person responsible for his nuclear family, has set a goal to give his children and wife better living conditions through the reconstruction of his humble home. Through the years that they have lived there, the home has been deteriorating and conditions continually worsening for its inhabitants.

For this reason Mr. Carlos initiated part of the reconstruction of his home by investing financial resources in order to fulfill his dream of having better living conditions. Nonetheless, after beginning the work he needed to stop for financial reasons, and because of this he is requesting a loan from Ceprodel. He will purchase construction materials and continue the reconstruction of his home with the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Carlos Guillermo O. como padre de familia y responsable de su núcleo familiar, se ha propuesto la meta de brindarle a sus hijos y esposa mejores condiciones de vida por medio de la reconstrucción de su humilde casa de habitación ya que ha medida que han transcurrido los años esta se ha venido deteriorando y brindando malas condiciones para habitar en ella.

Por este motivo es que el señor Carlos al haber iniciado parte de la reconstrucción de su casa ha invertido recursos económicos para llevar a cabo su sueño de tener mejores condiciones de vida. Sin embargo, al haber iniciado esta labor decidió detener la obra por el factor económico, por esta única razón busca un financiamiento en Ceprodel con el único fin de comprar los materiales de construcción para continuar con la obra de reconstrucción de su casa de habitación.

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Thy T., 43, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Heang Toeu (pictured above), and their eight children. She works in the fields as a farmer and typically makes US$ 1.50 each day, while her husband is a fisherman and makes US$ 8 each day. The family is also supported by the employment of two sons who are local blacksmiths.

Fishing has been difficult this year in Cambodia and inflation problems have impacted all Cambodians. Thy T. has asked for a loan of US$ 700 to purchase some new fishing equipment for her husband's business. With new equipment, he can increase his daily catch and also the family’s daily income. She believes this investment can also help her family improve its standard of living in the long term.

loans.use: Purchase fishing equipment

loans.name: Theoneste

texts.en:
Greetings from Rwamagana in Rwanda! Theoneste is 28 years old, married with two children, one adopted after being orphaned in the 1994 Genocide in Rwanda. 

In 2000, Theoneste started a small shop in Rwamagana’s trading center selling a variety of items including soap, sugar, cassava flour, soft drinks, and clothes. He later expanded his business by growing sorghum and bananas to sell in the markets in order to increase his income. Currently employing four people and earning about $100 every month, Theoneste is applying for a loan of $925 to increase the stock in his shop and grow more sorghum and bananas.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Song

texts.en:
Song L., 48, is a professional tailor who lives with three of her four children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. 

Since 2005, she has been a tailor to earn a living and is able to make around US$2 of profit per day. She is aided by one of her children, who works as a garment factory worker. Her husband, Sreng Chheang, 52, is a motorbike mechanic. On average, he earns US$2 of profit per day.

Mrs. Song would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of US$500 to purchase more cloth for her business and also add one more sewing machine. (Mr. Sreng is pictured because Mrs. Song was not available.)

loans.use: To purchase more cloth for her business and also add one more sewing machine.

loans.name: Samaddin

texts.en: Samaddin is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town. He is settled in the Fizuli region, Bala Bahmanli village. He was born in 1980. This man is married and has 2 children. Five years ago he started the cattle breeding business. Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy 2 calves for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy 2 calves

loans.name: Arilowé

texts.fr: Née vers 1973 à Sakété dans le département du Plateau au sud du BENIN, dame A. Arilowé est mariée et mère deux enfants. Mariée à Razack BABALOLA, elle voyage sur Lomé pour l'approvisionnement de ses articles qu'elle vient distribuer à ses clients avant de vendre à petit coup le reste. Désireuse de renforcer ses capacités et couvrir la demande de ses clients elle demande ce crédit pour également faire face à la concurrence.
texts.en:
Born around 1973 in Sakété in the Plateau Province in the south of Benin, Mrs. Arilowé A. is married and the mother of two children. Married to Razack Babalola, she travels to Lomé to buy the articles she distributes to her clients, before selling whatever is left over retail. Wishing to reinforce her business and meet her customers' demand, she is requesting this loan so that she can stand up to the competition.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 6 dozen pairs of shoes and 2 dozen handbags

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is 45 years old and married with 4 children. She has a restaurant where she sells cooked food like rice, beans, plantains, etc. She has lots of customers who patronize her restaurant. Helen needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs for cooking and also drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Nanda Kumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Nanda Kumari M., 25 years old, lives in Thecho, Laltipur, Nepal. Most of the people in this area are engaged in agricultural work. Mrs. M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband, one son, and one daughter. Her daughter is studying in grade 3 and her son is in pre-primary school.

Mrs. M.’s husband's name is Mr. Daya Ram M. and he is a carpenter. He makes different types of furniture such as "almirahs" (chests of drawers), tables, beds, etc. Nowadays in that region, the demand for these sorts of furniture is constantly increasing. So Mrs. M. is requesting for her second loan of Rs 15,000 to help her husband buy more lumber for his furniture work.

loans.use: To buy lumber for his furniture-making

loans.name: Mokhtabar

texts.en: Mokhtabar A. lives in Sabirabad, Azerbaijan. He is 47 years old, married, and has five children. Mokhtabar is the sole provider for his family and earns his living by raising and selling livestock. He purchases young calves from local villagers, raises them for 5-7 months, and then sells the adult cows and bulls to local butchers. Mokhtabar is thinking about expanding his business, because his current earnings are not enough to provide for his family. He wants to purchase more calves and fodder. He is requesting a loan of US $1,200 for the term of 15 months. Mokhtabar appreciates your helping him so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals.

loans.use: To purchase two baby calves and fodder

loans.name: Djiguissèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè de l’association Djiguignouman sont au nombre de quatre (trois mariées et une veuve). Elles vivent dans des familles monogamiques avec en moyenne 28 ans et  2 enfants dans le village de Ségou coura Bamanan (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles sont toutes membres d’une même association traditionnelle et font les activités de commerce d’articles divers (pagnes, savon, ustensiles de cuisine, céréales et fruits et légumes etc.). 
C’est dans leurs recherches de ressources financières complémentaires qu’elles ont fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 1er prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire).
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter 12 douzaines de tasses inoxydables, 24 pièces  de pagnes wax (tissus très prisés en Afrique de l’ouest) et 13 cartons de savon de lessive. Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des grossistes au grand marché de Ségou pour l’ensemble de ces articles qui sont revendus au marché du château de la ville de Ségou puis en ambulant dans les quartiers du village de Ségou coura, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle majoritairement composée de femmes.
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23 800FCA qui sera épargné et  utilisé pour la prise en charge des frais scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
There are four women in the Djiguissèmè group from the Djiguignouman association (three are married and one is a widow). They live in monogamous families in the village of Ségou Coura Bamana (Mali's fourth administrative region) and have an average age of 28 and an average of two children each. They all belong to the same traditional association and have a business selling miscellaneous items (traditional African cloth, soap, cooking utensils, cereal, fruit, nuts, etc.). In their search for additional financing, they turned to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first group (i.e. solidarity) loan with the institution. The loan will be used to buy 12 dozen stainless steel bowls, 24 pieces of waxed cloth (highly regarded in West Africa) and 13 boxes of laundry soap. Most of their supplies come from wholesalers at the main market in Ségou, and they sell them either at the Château market (also in Ségou) or by walking around the neighborhoods of the village of Ségou-Coura to a clientele consisting mainly of women who pay cash or buy on credit. The women hope to make a monthly profit of CFA 23,800 which they will save up and use to pay for their children’s school fees.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bowls, waxed cloth and soap

loans.name: Rehana Kosar M. Javed Group

texts.en:
Rehana Kosar baji is a 25-year-old married woman and has been a citizen Borewala, Pakistan for the past 6 years. Her husband, M.J., is a delivery man. He uses his donkey cart to transport items from one place to another. 

Rehana baji has two daughters. Neither are school-aged. Her husband’s earning is insufficient, which forced her to do some work. She prepares embroidered dresses and takes care of her daughters as well. She charges $3 per embroidered dress. She is applying for a loan for her husband because his cart has become rough and it doesn’t allow him to load anything. 

She is the leader of a group of women in her locality. Sajida baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Kishwar baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics for her parlor. Rukhsana baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle, like a tuk-tuk). Sawran baji wants a loan to by a donkey cart for loading. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: 'Baji,' which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart

loans.name: Arslan

texts.ru: Палванов Арслан проживает в районе Джилликуль. Женат и имеет четверых детей. Занимается торговлей. В сфере бизнеса работает уже три года. Имеет магазин по продаже автозапчастей. Его бизнес является единственным источником дохода его семьи. Поэтому он планирует развивать дело . Для этого он решил получить кредит сроком на 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Arslan P. lives in Jilikul. He is married and has four children. He works in sales. He has been in business for three years. He has an auto parts shop. This business is the only source of income for his family. Therefore, he plans to develop the business. In order to do that, he has decided to take out a loan for twelve months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase sales

loans.name: Ore-Oluwa

texts.en: Ore-Oluwa is 32 years old and married with three children.  She sells female clothes.  Ore-Oluwa is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more clothes to sell.  She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more female clothes to sell.

loans.name: Daniel Isaías

texts.es: Daniel Isaías M. de 39 años de edad reside en Soyapango junto a su esposa y su hijo. Daniel posee una panadería, en la cual trabaja ya desde hace 15 años, el no posee empleados en dicho negocio únicamente la ayuda de su hermana a la cual le da un pago simbólico de $100 dólares mensuales. Daniel solicita un préstamo para comprar una vitrina para colocar el pan y un pick up para poder distribuirlo de manera más rápida y segura, es así como él espera mejorar su negocio, lo cual le ayudara mucho a poder percibir mayores ganancias
texts.en:
Daniel Isaias M. is 39-years old and resides in Soyapango with his wife and child. Daniel owns a bakery where he has worked for the last 15-years. He does not have any employees as his sister helps out with the business and he pays her a $100/monthly as a gesture. Daniel requests a loan to purchase a showcase to place the bread and a commercial paddle to distribute the bread efficiently and safely. This is how he hopes to improve the business, which will in turn give him higher profits.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase a commerical paddle and a showcase.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing garments

loans.name: Chi's Group

texts.en:
This is a small group comprised of five borrowers, all of whom live in the province of Siem Reap. Its leader, Mrs. Chi T., 39, is a widowed mother who has three children. All three of them are single and attend school. She usually sells fresh fish that she buys in bulk from a wholesale supplier and then retails them for a profit in the local market. In the business, Chi T. has attracted a number of customers who come to buy her fish because she has a skill in communication and sells at a better price in the market. In order to meet more of her customer's needs, she would like a loan to accrue a quantity of fresh fish to sell. The other four borrowers who have joined this loan:
Mrs. K. will be using a loan to buy more tools for her fishing business.
Mrs. R. is fish catcher, who is asking for a loan to purchase a boat to use for fishing.
Mr. C. is a fish-carrying worker, who is applying for a loan to repair his old house.
Mrs. T. will be using the loan money to support her fishing business activities.

loans.use: To purchase a quantity of fresh fish to sell.

loans.name: Fatma

texts.fr: fatma D. est parent beneficiaire a cmberenedepuis 1997.elle est commercante de tissus et capitalise six ans d'experience.elle sollicite ce credit de 100 000frs pour repondre a la demnde accroissante de ses clients.l'augmentation de son fond pourra engendrer la maximalisation de ses benefices.
texts.en:
Fatma D. has been a client parent in Camberene since 1997. She is a merchant of cloth and capitalizes on six years of experience. She’s requesting this loan of 100,000 francs to respond to the growing demand of her customers. Augmenting her funds will result in maximizing her profits.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Hafiz

texts.en: Hafiz M. is 43,  married and has 3 children. He started his own business in 1996 because his salary as an engineer wasn’t enough for the family expenses. Hafiz, together with the help of his wife, sells food such as butter, tea, cookies, and pastries, in the local market. The generated income allows Hafiz to support his family. He dreams of educating all of his children with a higher education. Today, he is requesting a loan of 2000 USD that he will use to expand the range of goods he sells. The income he will receive will be spent on the well-being of his family, as well as for his children's education.

loans.use: expand the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Naida

texts.en:
In order to help contribute to the family income, Naida J. owns and manages a small sari-sari store that sells variety goods in their village. With a supportive husband, she hopes that her business will help her child achieve as much education as possible. To boost family income, Naida is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 to buy more merchandise to attract a larger clientele.

She participates every time there is a CEVI cluster meeting in their barrio. In addition to loans, the CEVI program offers education that helps entrepreneurs effectively develop their businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise.

loans.name: Ruth Belia

texts.es:
Ruth Belia López G. es una señora de 36 años de edad, quien vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada Cuatro Bocas de Upala, localizada en la Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y leche) y agricultura.

Desde hace ya varios años doña Ruth se dedica a la ganadería de doble propósito. Logra vender sus  productos a los vecinos de su comunidad quienes se muestran muy satisfechos con la calidad de los productos que ofrece. 

Doña Ruth  considera que gracias al progreso de este proyecto, ella y su familia han mejorado poco a poco sus condiciones de vida y ha logrado ser participe en el desarrollo de la comunidad, también comenta que desde que inicio con el negocio su autoestima ha mejorado mucho y ahora se siente muy capaz.

En estos momentos doña Ruth desea obtener un microcrédito  por ¢650,000 (seiscientos cincuenta mil colones), para comprar 6 terneros machos y así  poder incrementar la producción. Ella sabe que contar con mayor número de vacas más es un mayor sacrificio y demandará más trabajo. Sin embargo, el deseo de ser una microempresaria exitosa y  sacar adelante a su familia mejorando las condiciones de vida, la motiva a esforzarse con gran esmero y dedicación.

Doña Ruth es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Bansuperafe; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su cuarto  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Ruth Belia López G. is a 36 year old woman who lives with her husband and 2 children. She lives in a small rural community in Costa Rica called Cuatro de Bocas de Upala, located in the province of Alajuela. There, they have business activities such as storekeeping, dual purpose cattle farming (meat and dairy), and agriculture.

Ruth has been involved in dual purpose cattle farming for several years now. She is able to sell her products to neighbors in her community, who are very satisfied with the quality of the products that she offers.

Ruth thinks that thanks to the progress of this project, she and her family have improved, little by little, their quality of life and that she has been able to be a participant in the development of the community. She also comments that since the beginning of the business, her self-esteem has increased greatly and now she feels very capable.

Right now, Ruth would like a loan of 650,000 CRC to purchase 6 male calves so that she can increase her production. She knows that having more cows is a bigger sacrifice and will require more work. However, her desire to have a successful small business and help her family get ahead and improve their living conditions motivates her to work with great care and dedication.

Ruth is a member of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal Bansuperafe, which consists of only women. It specializes in supporting women who are not professionals or the head of household. It is one of EDESA’s 100 partner organizations in Costa Rica. This will be Ruth’s fourth loan and with it, she hopes to continue growing on a personal and economic level, in addition to actively participating in the loan organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 6 calves

loans.name: Naima

texts.en:
Naima is a member of the Dodoma Road in Kihesa,Iringa,she is 23 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 6 and 1 years.

Naima started her own business selling clothes and tomatoes 5 years ago,she works 9 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 950,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Naima`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes and tomatoes.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,naima hopes to save money,pay school fees and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Maria Esperanza

texts.es: Maria Esperanza T. T. tiene 48 años. Es una Señora que ha tenido muchas necesidades por lo que ha recurrido a realizar préstamos a Fundación León 2000. Su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 20 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que siempre le ha gustado luchar y sacar adelante a sus hijos. El mayor desafío que enfrento fue la salud por lo que no tenía el suficiente capital para empezar este medio de vida. Ella solicita este financiamiento destinado para capital de trabajo para la compra de pan, galletas, detergentes, jabón y refrescos naturales. Su mayor deseo es seguir proporcionándole a su familia el alimento de cada dia.
texts.en:
Maria Esperanza T. T. is 48 years old and a woman who has many needs. As a result, she has applied for several loans from Fundación León 2000. She has a grocery store and has managed her business for more than 20 years. Maria has always enjoyed the challenge of trying to succeed for her children.

Her greatest difficulty has been with her health because she does not have enough income to maintain her way of life. The loan she requested will be used as operating capital to buy bread, cookies, detergents, soaps, and natural beverages. Her greatest desire is to continue providing for her family’s daily needs.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bread, cookies, detergents, soaps, and natural beverages

loans.name: Juana De La Concepcion

texts.es: La Señora Juana de la Concepción M. tiene 66 años, su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 4 años que se dedica a este negocio. Juana tiene 1 hija a su cargo que asiste a una escuela especial, ya que tiene problemas de aprendizaje y con mucha más razón son sus motivos para salir adelante y aportar los ingresos necesarios para su familia. Ella se levanta muy temprano todos los días ya que tiene que preparar sus refrescos naturales, bolsitas y tiene que traer pan en un panadería que está ubicada cerca de su casa ya que es aquí donde obtiene más favorable el pan. Juana solicita financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será destinado para granos básicos, productos congelados, golosinas, detergentes, pan entre otros. Su deseo es proporcionarle mejores condiciones de vida a su hija.
texts.en:
Juana de la Concepción M. is 66. She has a mini market. She has been in this business for over four years. Juana has a daughter she cares for. She goes to a special school because she has learning problems. This and many other reasons are her motivation to get ahead and provide her family with the necessary income. She gets up very early every day because she has to prepare her natural soft drinks and bags. She has to fetch the bread in a bakery, which is located close to her house. That is where she gets the best bread. Juana is asking for a loan to buy basic grains, frozen products, sweets, detergent, and bread, among other things. Her wish is to give her daughter better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de viande de bœufs, il exerce son commerce dans l’enceinte de l’abattoir du grand marché de Lomé. Les tenanciers de restaurant viennent s’approvisionner chez lui. Actuellement la demande de ses clients est élevée mais les balances qu’il utilise pour peser la marchandise sont usées, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter une balance électrique et deux (02) balances ordinaires.
Il est marié et père de 05 enfants, c’est avec le revenu de cette activité qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman has income-generating work selling beef. He operates in the slaughterhouse enclosure at the grand market of Lomé. Restaurant owners come to him to stock up. Currently, customer demand is high. But the scales he uses to weigh the merchandise are worn. He’s requesting a WAGES loan to buy an electronic scale and two ordinary scales. He is married and the father of five children. With the revenues from this business, he provides for his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy balances
